|Rank=A
|Title=Know the principles of treatment of hypocalcaemia
|Description=Know the principles of calcium and vitamin D supplementation.
|Rubric=Management
|Contributors=P. RIEU M. FLAMANT B. MOULIN
|Order=40}}

*Treatment of the cause if possible, such as stopping treatment, correcting vitamin D deficiency or hypomagnesaemia.

*Symptomatic treatment
**Calcium per os (calcium carbonate): 500 mg to 1.5 g/day between meals (500 mg/day only if chronic renal failure).
**Parenteral calcium (calcium gluconate or calcium chloride) in cases of severe symptomatic hypocalcaemia (care must be taken to avoid extravasation).

*Special cases
**Chronic renal failure
***Supplementation with vitamin D hydroxylated in position 1 (Un-Alfa®) or 1.25 (Rocaltrol®) provided there is no significant hyperphosphatemia.
***Calcium intake
**Hypoparathyroidism
***Supplementation with vitamin D hydroxylated in position 1 (Un-Alfa®) or 1.25 (Rocaltrol®)
***Calcium intake
***Monitor calciuria (significant risk of hypercalciuria)
**Rhabdomyolysis
***Calcium intake only if symptomatic (risk of rebound hypercalcaemia)

question.title: What is the recommended calcium supplementation for patients with chronic renal failure?
question.description: What is the recommended calcium supplementation for patients with chronic renal failure?

option_b.title: Vitamin D hydroxylated in position 1 (Un-Alfa®) or 1.25 (Rocaltrol®) and calcium intake
option_b.description: Supplementation with vitamin D and calcium

option_d.title: Calcium gluconate or calcium chloride and vitamin D hydroxylated in position 1 (Un-Alfa®) or 1.25 (Rocaltrol®)
option_d.description: Combination of parenteral and oral calcium supplementation
